skill.name: expo-deployment
skill.description: Deploying Expo apps to iOS App Store, Android Play Store, web hosting, and API routes
skill.summary: Deploy Expo apps to iOS App Store, Android Play Store, web hosting, and API routes using EAS CLI
skill.author: expo

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. This is a documentation skill containing markdown files with example CLI commands. The scanner incorrectly flagged markdown code fences as shell backticks, algorithm names as weak crypto implementations, and configuration examples as credential access. No executable code exists in this skill.

critical_findings.title: Heuristic: Dangerous Combination
critical_findings.description: Scanner flagged 'Code execution + Network + Credential access' combination. This is a documentation skill with example deployment commands. No actual dangerous code execution occurs.
critical_findings.confidence_reasoning: Scanner heuristic triggered by example commands in documentation. No actual code execution or credential exfiltration exists.

high_findings.title: Credential JSON File References
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged JSON examples containing service account key paths. These are configuration documentation examples, not actual credential files.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation examples showing JSON configuration syntax for service account paths. No actual credentials or credential files present.

high_findings.title: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm References
high_findings.description: Scanner detected algorithm names in documentation text. These are mentions in documentation, not actual cryptographic implementations.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Algorithm names in documentation text discussing encryption standards. No actual cryptographic implementations exist.

high_findings.title: Environment File Access Documentation
high_findings.description: Scanner flagged environment variable documentation. These are legitimate documentation about configuration using environment variables.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation about using environment variables for configuration in CI/CD pipelines. Standard practice, not a security issue.

medium_findings.title: Shell Command Documentation
medium_findings.description: Scanner flagged shell command examples in markdown code blocks. These are documentation examples, not actual command execution.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Markdown code blocks containing EAS CLI command examples. Standard documentation practice, no actual command execution.

low_findings.title: Network URL References
low_findings.description: Scanner detected hardcoded URLs in documentation. These are legitimate reference URLs for platform documentation.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation URLs linking to official platform documentation (Apple, Google, Expo). Standard practice.

low_findings.title: System Command References
low_findings.description: Scanner flagged build monitoring commands as 'system reconnaissance'. These are legitimate EAS CLI commands for checking build status.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: EAS CLI commands for build monitoring and submission (eas build:list, eas build:view, eas submit:list). Standard deployment operations.

content.user_title: Deploy Expo apps to app stores
content.value_statement: Deploying Expo apps to app stores requires understanding complex CLI commands, platform-specific configurations, and submission processes. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for deploying to iOS App Store, Android Play Store, TestFlight, and web using EAS CLI.
actual_capabilities: Generate EAS CLI commands for iOS and Android builds
Configure eas.json with production build and submit profiles
Set up App Store Connect API keys and Google Play service accounts
Create CI/CD workflows for automated deployments
Submit builds to TestFlight for beta testing
Deploy web apps using EAS Hosting
limitations: Does not execute commands directly - provides command examples for user execution
Does not store or handle credentials - users must manage their own credentials
Does not modify project files without user confirmation
Cannot submit builds to stores without proper authentication configured

use_cases.title: First-time app submission
use_cases.description: First-time Expo developers need guidance setting up credentials and submitting their initial build to the iOS App Store or Google Play Store.
use_cases.target_user: New Expo developers preparing their first production release

use_cases.title: CI/CD automation
use_cases.description: Developers want to automate deployments using GitHub Actions or other CI providers with EAS Workflows for consistent, repeatable releases.
use_cases.target_user: DevOps engineers and team leads setting up automated release pipelines

use_cases.title: Beta testing programs
use_cases.description: Teams need to quickly push updates to TestFlight or internal testing tracks for QA feedback before production release.
use_cases.target_user: QA teams and product managers managing beta testing programs

prompt_templates.title: Quick build and submit
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the EAS CLI commands to build and submit my Expo app to the iOS App Store for production release.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants immediate commands for their first App Store submission

prompt_templates.title: Android Play Store setup
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I configure Google Play service account credentials for automated Android submissions using EAS?
prompt_templates.scenario: User needs help setting up Android Play Store credentials

prompt_templates.title: CI/CD workflow creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an EAS Workflow YAML file that builds for both iOS and Android on main branch pushes and submits automatically.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to set up automated CI/CD deployment

prompt_templates.title: EAS configuration optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my eas.json configuration and suggest improvements for faster builds and proper version management for production releases.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to optimize their EAS configuration

output_examples.input: How do I submit to TestFlight?
output_examples.output:
Use the EAS Submit command to send your iOS build to TestFlight:

```bash
eas build -p ios --profile production --submit
```

Or submit a specific build by ID:

```bash
eas submit -p ios --id BUILD_ID
```

For quick TestFlight testing during development, you can also use:

```bash
npx testflight
```

Make sure you have configured your App Store Connect API key or Apple ID credentials first.

best_practices: Use App Store Connect API keys instead of Apple ID to avoid 2FA issues in CI/CD pipelines
Set up EAS Secrets for credentials instead of committing service account files to version control
Test builds on internal testing tracks before submitting to production to catch issues early
anti_patterns: Committing service account JSON keys or API credentials to version control
Using personal Apple ID accounts for team deployments instead of proper API keys
Skipping internal testing and submitting directly to production without validation

faq.question: What credentials do I need for iOS App Store submission?
faq.answer: You need either an App Store Connect API key (recommended for CI/CD) or an Apple ID with App Manager role. The API key consists of a .p8 file, issuer ID, and key ID. Configure these in eas.json or use environment variables.

faq.question: How do I automate deployments with GitHub Actions?
faq.answer: Use EAS Workflows to define build and submit steps in YAML. Combine with GitHub Actions to trigger workflows on branch pushes. EAS handles authentication using stored credentials or environment secrets.

faq.question: Can I deploy to both iOS and Android with a single command?
faq.answer: Yes, use `eas build --profile production` without the `-p` flag to build for both platforms. Add `--submit` to automatically submit both builds after successful compilation.

faq.question: What is the difference between internal, alpha, and production tracks?
faq.answer: Internal testing is for up to 100 testers within your organization. Alpha/closed beta extends testing to external testers. Production is the public release track visible to all users on the store.

faq.question: How do I handle version numbers for submissions?
faq.answer: Set `appVersionSource: "remote"` in eas.json to let EAS manage version numbers from App Store Connect or Play Console. Alternatively, use `eas build:version:set` to manually set version numbers.

faq.question: What happens if my submission gets rejected?
faq.answer: EAS provides submission status tracking. Address the rejection reasons, upload a new build with fixes, and resubmit. Use internal testing tracks to validate compliance before production submission.
